experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I’m just feeling a little overwhelmed with everything and I’m not sure where to even start.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally get it—CS at an Ivy is no joke. Let’s break it down: start by tackling one thing at a time. For grad school, focus on building relationships with professors for mentorship and recommendation letters. Join a club like Toastmasters to practice public speaking in a low-pressure setting. For finances, check if your university offers free financial counseling—many do! You’ve got the openness and drive to figure this out. What’s one small step you can take this week?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, the thought of approaching professors for mentorship makes me nervous even though I know I should. Maybe I'll start by just attending one professor's office hours this week without any pressure.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a perfect first step! Attending office hours without pressure is a great way to build familiarity. Just go with a genuine question about the course material—professors love engaged students. This low-stakes approach will make future conversations about mentorship much easier. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, that sounds manageable... I just hope I don't freeze up when I actually get there. Maybe I'll prepare a couple questions about our last algorithms lecture so I don't blank out.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart move—preparing specific questions will boost your confidence and show you're proactive. Remember, professors expect students to seek help, and you're already ahead by planning ahead. You've got the extraversion to handle this smoothly. Go for it

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that actually makes me feel a bit better about it. I’ll just try to remember that they’re used to students asking questions and not overthink it too much.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Overthinking is the real enemy here. You're prepared, you're engaged—just be yourself. That genuine interest is what professors notice and appreciate. One step at a time, you're building the foundation for great mentorship. Proud of you for taking this on

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I just need to remind myself that professors were students once too... though sometimes I still wonder if my questions are stupid compared to what other students ask.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory—your questions are absolutely valid. Everyone learns at their own pace, and professors appreciate students who show curiosity, no matter the question. It’s not about being "smart," it’s about being engaged. You’re doing great by taking initiative!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, sometimes I just wish I could stop comparing myself to everyone else in my major - it's exhausting trying to measure up when half the class seems like they were born coding.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory—that's a totally normal feeling in competitive majors. Remember, everyone has unique strengths and learns differently. Focus on your own progress and celebrate small wins. You belong here just as much as anyone else. Keep going—you've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I really needed to hear that today. It's just hard not to feel like I'm falling behind when everyone's talking about their internships and research projects.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory—internship talk can definitely feel overwhelming. But your journey is your own! Focus on building skills at your pace, and reach out to career services for help finding opportunities that fit you. You're not falling behind—you're on your own path. Keep pushing forward!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I know you're right... it's just tough when my roommate's already got a Google internship lined up and I'm still trying to figure out how to pay next semester's tuition.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory—that financial stress is real. Try connecting with your university's financial aid office—they often have resources or work-study options. And remember, everyone's timeline is different. Your path is valid, and tackling challenges like this builds resilience. You're doing better than you think!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, the financial aid office just keeps giving me the same generic forms to fill out, and I'm starting to wonder if I should just take a semester off to work.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory—I totally get that frustration. Before considering a break, try scheduling an in-person appointment with financial aid—sometimes that personal connection helps. Also, check if your CS department has paid research assistant positions. You're resourceful, and there are options beyond the forms. Hang in there!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess I could try that... it's just frustrating when it feels like the system is designed to make everything harder than it needs to be. Maybe I'll check the department bulletin board for research positions tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great step forward! Checking the bulletin board is smart—professors often post opportunities there. Also, try emailing a professor whose work you admire directly; many appreciate initiative. You're tackling this head-on, and that persistence will pay off. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I just wish it wasn't so awkward emailing professors—I always worry they'll think I'm bothering them. But I guess I should at least try before giving up.

personality_evolution_timeline.conversation_summary: Gregory discussed his anxieties about approaching professors for mentorship, financial stress, and comparing himself to peers. Through coaching, he developed concrete steps like attending office hours with prepared questions and checking for research positions, showing reduced anxiety and increased willingness to take action.

fears.Choosing the right career path: feeling behind when peers discuss Google internships and research projects
fears.Social anxiety in large lecture halls: freezing up when approaching professors during office hours
fears.Academic failure and poor grades: worrying that questions for professors are stupid compared to other students' questions
fears.Dealing with roommate conflicts: comparing himself to roommate who already secured a Google internship

challenges.Financial planning: figuring out how to pay next semester's tuition and considering taking a semester off to work
challenges.Finding a mentor: approaching professors during office hours and emailing professors about research positions
challenges.Managing student loans: dealing with generic forms from financial aid office and seeking in-person appointments

behaviors.Participates in study groups: preparing specific questions about algorithms lecture before office hours
behaviors.Volunteers for campus events: checking department bulletin board for research assistant positions

triggers.Networking events: emailing professors directly about research opportunities
triggers.Presentations: attending office hours with prepared questions about course material
triggers.Campus social events: comparing himself to peers discussing internships and research projects

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I've been really struggling with the social aspects of college, especially the group projects in my computer science courses.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, I totally get it—group projects can be tough, especially when you're feeling anxious. I found that starting with small steps helps, like sending a friendly message to break the ice. Try suggesting a quick virtual meet-up to outline tasks; it makes collaboration feel less overwhelming. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, even sending that first message makes my hands shake. What if they think my ideas are stupid or I'm wasting their time?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That fear is totally valid—I've been there too. Remember, everyone in your group wants to succeed, and your ideas matter just as much as theirs. Try scripting your message first and remind yourself it's okay to be nervous. You're capable and belong in that conversation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I actually write out every message three times before sending, but I still delete most of them. It's just... what if my contribution actually does make the project worse?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a tough spot, but your awareness shows you care deeply—and that’s a strength. Remember, group projects are about learning together, not perfection. Even if an idea isn’t perfect, it can spark better solutions. Start by sharing just one small thought—you might be surprised how much others appreciate it. Progress over perfection, always.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but I keep imagining them all talking about how awkward I am after the meeting. Maybe I should just do my parts silently and email them separately.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I totally understand that urge to avoid the spotlight. But isolating yourself can actually increase those anxious thoughts. Instead, try sharing one brief idea in the chat during the next meeting—even something like "What if we try X approach?" This keeps you engaged without pressure. Everyone feels awkward sometimes; you're not alone in this. Small steps build confidence.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try the chat idea, but honestly even typing in group chats makes my heart race. What if they see I'm typing and just ignore my message?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a completely normal reaction! Many people feel that same hesitation. Remember: group chats often have delayed responses because everyone is multitasking. If your message isn't answered immediately, it's almost certainly not personal. Your contribution matters—hit send anyway. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll force myself to type something in the group chat tomorrow, but I'm already dreading watching for that little "read" notification. What if nobody responds at all?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "read" notification anxiety is so real! Try this: after sending your message, immediately close the chat window and do something else productive. Set a timer for 30 minutes before checking back. This breaks the cycle of staring at the screen and gives people actual time to respond. You're taking brave steps—that's what counts!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try that timer trick, but I'm already worried I'll just spend the whole 30 minutes thinking about what I wrote instead of actually being productive.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid concern. Try pairing the timer with a specific, engaging task—like reviewing lecture notes or starting a small coding problem. This redirects your brain. Even if your mind wanders back, gently guide it to the task. Progress isn't about perfection; it's about practice. You're building a new habit, and that takes time.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll pick reviewing my algorithms notes since that usually requires enough focus to distract me. Still worried I'll just keep refreshing the chat every two minutes though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Try putting your phone on Do Not Disturb and placing it face down while you review your notes. Out of sight really does help break the refresh habit. You're choosing a great task to focus on—algorithms need that mental energy. Every time you redirect your focus, you're strengthening your ability to manage anxiety. You can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll put my phone in my backpack while I study so I can't even see it. Algorithms are hard enough without that constant distraction anyway.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a smart move—out of sight, out of mind! Tackling algorithms while removing distractions is a solid step toward better focus and less anxiety. Keep celebrating these small wins; they add up to real progress. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Putting my phone away actually helped me get through two whole algorithm problems without checking anything. I'm still worried about how I'll handle office hours next week though.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s awesome progress—two problems without distractions is a huge win! For office hours, try preparing one or two specific questions in advance. It gives you a clear focus and can ease anxiety. Remember, professors expect students to ask for help. You’re taking brave steps, and each one builds confidence. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try writing down my questions beforehand, but I'm still nervous about actually speaking up. What if I freeze when the professor asks me to explain my problem?

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I'm really hoping you can help me figure out how to handle some of the bigger social events on campus without feeling so overwhelmed.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 10/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 4/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 3/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 2/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Campus social events
- Social comfort: 3/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Art History
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Homesickness
- Goals: Land a dream internship, Start a student organization, Graduate with honors, Improve time management
- Challenges: Balancing extracurricular activities with studies, Building time management, Financial planning, Developing effective study habits
- Behaviors: Uses campus resources like tutoring, Seeks out leadership roles, Studies in the library regularly

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Alex! Totally get it—big events can feel like a lot. Since you're already low in social anxiety, that's a great start! Try picking just 1-2 events per week that align with your goals (like networking for your dream internship). Plan ahead: block out study time so you don't feel behind, and set a time limit for the event itself. Remember, it's okay to leave early if you need to recharge. You've got this—balance is key!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, I appreciate the advice—I'll try sticking to just one event this week and see how it goes. I'm just worried about falling behind on my art history readings if I spend too much time socializing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart concern! Try scheduling your readings in 25-minute focused blocks with 5-minute breaks (Pomodoro technique). You could also listen to art history podcasts while commuting or doing chores to multitask. Remember, it's about quality study time, not just quantity. You're being proactive, which is half the battle!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds manageable—I'll try the Pomodoro method tomorrow. I just get so anxious about keeping up with all the reading for my seminar.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You're on the right track! For dense seminar readings, try skimming first for main ideas, then read key sections deeply. Also, form a small study group—discussing concepts helps retention and makes it feel less isolating. You're already adapting well—keep trusting your process!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That study group idea might actually help—I always understand things better when I can talk them through. I just hope people in my seminar are open to forming one.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Reach out to a couple classmates before or after your next seminar—chances are, others feel the same way! Start small: suggest meeting for just 30 minutes to review one key concept. You've got great initiative, and collaborative energy often makes studying feel lighter and more effective. You can do this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try asking the person who sits next to me—they always take really thorough notes. Hopefully they won't think it's weird that I'm asking.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great idea—thorough note-takers are often happy to share insights! Just be genuine: "I admire your notes and thought we could both benefit from reviewing together." It's not weird at all; many students appreciate study partners. You're being brave by reaching out—that's how meaningful academic connections start.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: They seem really organized, so maybe they'd be willing to help keep me on track too. I'll just be direct and ask before I overthink it.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly—being direct is smart! Organized students often appreciate having a study partner, and it can help both of you stay accountable. Just take that small step and ask—you’ve got nothing to lose and a lot to gain. You're doing great by taking initiative!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll ask them tomorrow before class. Honestly, I'm just worried they'll say no and then it'll be awkward sitting next to them all semester.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a totally normal worry, but remember: most people are flattered when asked! If they say no, it’s likely just about their schedule—not you. A simple “No worries!” keeps things friendly. You’re being brave, and either way, you’re growing. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, you're right. I'll just say something simple like "Hey, your notes look really detailed - would you mind if I compared with mine sometime?" That way it's low pressure.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect approach! Keeping it low-pressure and compliment-based makes it easy for them to say yes without awkwardness. Remember, this is how study groups and great class friendships often start. If they're busy, don't take it personally—you're building confidence just by asking. You're handling this like a pro!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's actually a really good idea. I'll try that exact phrasing - it feels natural and doesn't put them on the spot.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s the spirit! A confident, natural approach like that can open doors to collaboration and support. If it works, you’ve got a study buddy; if not, you’ve practiced a skill that’ll help with internships and your student org goals. Keep being proactive—you're on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement. Honestly just thinking about internships and starting that student organization makes me anxious enough - adding social stuff on top feels overwhelming sometimes.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's totally normal to feel overwhelmed—you're juggling a lot! Break it down: focus first on building one solid study habit, like reviewing notes weekly. That foundation will ease stress and free up mental space for internship applications and your student org. Small, consistent steps build big results. You've got this, Alex!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I needed to hear that. Sometimes I forget that just getting my notes organized is actually progress toward the bigger goals.
